awd_titl_txt: EAGER: INFORMATE: Improving networks for organizational repositories through metadata augmentation, transformation and evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to analyze the interaction of many components of the scientific communication ecosystem, characterized for purposes of this project as the Global Research Infrastructure (GRI).   Core questions for analysis include how the scientific field measures the impact and benefits of research funding in the U.S.  This is a challenging task, requiring careful analysis and characterization of data and tools for collecting and presenting it, and understanding the breadth and capabilities of the entire  infrastructure.  Several key aggregate data repositories will be utilized for this early concept research, notably centering on the CHORUS alliance of scientific publishing information.  CHORUS provides analysis ready extracts from the GRI, and currently acts as an interface between publishers and 12 federal agencies, providing a proxy for the broader infrastructure. The project will 1) characterize available CHORUS data, focusing on sources and connections, 2) determine connectivity for funder and researcher identifiers and organization affiliations, 3) search for and find currently missing identifiers for organizations, 4) discover collaborations across funders, organizations, and datasets in journal article metadata, and 5) compare CHORUS and agency repository content to understand the contributions and limitations of both sets. This project will help federal agencies understand the capabilities of the Global Research Infrastructure and jump start understanding of new metadata sources and impact assessment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The Global Research infrastructure (GRI) is made up of the repositories and organizations that provide persistent identifiers (PIDs) and metadata for many kinds of research objects and connect these objects to funders, research institutions, researchers, and one another using PIDs. The INFORMATE Project has combined three data sources to focus on understanding how the global research infrastructure might help the US National Science Foundation (NSF) and other federal agencies identify and characterize the impact of their support. We made observations of three data systems. The NSF Award database represents NSF funding while the NSF Public Access Repository (PAR) and CHORUS, as a proxy for the GRI, represent two different view of results of that funding. We compare the first at the level of awards and the second two at the level of published research articles.

Our findings demonstrate that CHORUS datasets include significantly more NSF awards and more related papers than does PAR. Our findings also suggest that time plays a significant role in the inclusion of award metadata across the sources analyzed. Data in those sources travel very different journeys, each presenting different obstacles to metadata completeness and suggesting necessary actions on the parts of authors and publishers to ensure that publication and funding metadata are captured. We discuss these actions, as well as implications our findings have for emergent technologies such as artificial intelligence and natural language processing.

Keywords: Global research infrastructure; persistent identifiers; PIDs; metadata; research impact; NSF Public Access Repository, CHORUS, data journey

Project Goals:

1.    Provide a detailed description of CHORUS data reports and set stage for analysis.

2.    Determine quantitative baselines for Funder, Organization and People identifier coverage in the Global Research Infrastructure.

3.    Use global research infrastructure metadata to discover collaborations between multiple agencies, organizations, and datasets.

4.    Compare CHORUS and agency repositories to identify overlaps, differences, and opportunities for improvements.

Outcomes:

CHORUS provides a view of the Global Research Infrastructure as a connected network of repositories that track published papers, datasets, and other research outputs (Figure 1).  The journeys that data take through this infrastructure are complex and they must be understood to interpret the results correctly. Once understood, this connected system can be used to identify and connect research outputs funded by the U.S. Government.

The CHORUS view of the Global Research Infrastructure allows us to find where datasets funded by U.S. Geological Survey and U.S. National Science Foundation are preserved and managed (Figure 2). The USGS preserves many of the datasets they fund. Datasets funded by NSF, in contrast, are preserved in a variety of repositories.

The broad view provided by the Global Research Infrastructure makes it possible to identify datasets funded by multiple agencies (Figure 3). These reflect collaborations that take advantage of agency expertise and capabilities. 

Different data journeys require exploration of multiple sources to interpret the data (Figure 4). We compared two NSF data sources: 1) the Award Database and 2) the Public Access Repository with the Global Research Infrastructure as represented by CHORUS. 

We studied a sample of 51,602 awards and 307,549 associated research articles. We used CHORUS to identify awards and research articles (DOIs) that were not yet available from the NSF Public Access Repository (Figure 5).

The portion of articles (DOIs) available through the NSF Public Access Repository (PAR) has increased significantly over time and a change in NSF policy from suggested to required submission to PAR fueled that increase (Figure 6).

Conclusions:

These results demonstrate that multiple data sources must be considered to provide a complete measure of the extent of research results published with funding from the U.S. National Science Foundation. The journeys, i.e. sources and processing, of data from those sources must also be understood in interpreting the results. The coverage of published results in the NSF Public Access Repository is improving over time but it can be improved by considering the Global Research Infrastructure in addition to awardee input.

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Ray E Habermann

The Global Research infrastructure (GRI) is made up of the repositories and organizations that provide persistent identifiers (PIDs) and metadata for many kinds of research objects and connect these objects to funders, research institutions, researchers, and one another using PIDs. The INFORMATE Project has combined three data sources to focus on understanding how the global research infrastructure might help the US National Science Foundation (NSF) and other federal agencies identify and characterize the impact of their support. We compare the first at the level of awards and the second two at the level of published research articles.


Our findings demonstrate that CHORUS datasets include significantly more NSF awards and more related papers than does PAR. Our findings also suggest that time plays a significant role in the inclusion of award metadata across the sources analyzed. Data in those sources travel very different journeys, each presenting different obstacles to metadata completeness and suggesting necessary actions on the parts of authors and publishers to ensure that publication and funding metadata are captured. We discuss these actions, as well as implications our findings have for emergent technologies such as artificial intelligence and natural language processing.

4. Compare CHORUS and agency repositories to identify overlaps, differences, and opportunities for improvements.

The CHORUS view of the Global Research Infrastructure allows us to find where datasets funded by U.S. Geological Survey and U.S. National Science Foundation are preserved and managed (Figure 2). The broad view provided by the Global Research Infrastructure makes it possible to identify datasets funded by multiple agencies (Figure 3). These reflect collaborations that take advantage of agency expertise and capabilities.
